results.title: Rivers of delight: the Conway
results.brief_description: Broadcaster Wynford Vaughan-Thomas looks at the River Conway (Welsh spelling - Conwy) which rises in Snowdonia and reaches the sea on the North Wales coast at the town which bears its name. The Conway although only 30 miles long passes through landscape of immense variety starting as a fishing lake, gathering momentum at Betws-y-Coed, into the Swallow Falls and finally discharging into the sea at Conway Town.

results.title: Rivers in steel
results.creator_credit: Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures and Barry Merton
results.brief_description: Shows in detail the construction of penstocks at the Murray 1 and 2 Power Stations and explains briefly the Snowy Mountains Scheme and the benefits in irrigation from the inland diversion of rivers.

results.title: Rivers at work: an introduction to channel processes
results.brief_description: Introduces some of the basic concepts of fluvial geomorphology. Shows the processes which mould the landscape, indicates how field and laboratory observations provide insight into these processes, and gives a theoretical framework through which the study of rivers can be approached.

results.title: Rivers at work
results.creator_credit: Lew Davidson, Greenpark Productions, Film Producers Guild and Films of Scotland
results.brief_description: Modern development of her mountain waters to bring electrical power to Scotland began at Sloy. Like so many Scottish lochs, Sloy drew its water from only a small area of Highland country - not enough in itself for a massive power project. The collecting capacity of Sloy was consequently extended by means of tunnelling through the mountainsides to pipe the waters of neighbouring glens together. When this project was successfully completed, others were undertaken. Narrated by John Grierson. Photography, Arthur Lavis and John Wiles. Editing, John Tanner. Sound, Ron Abbott.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lew Davidson, Greenpark Productions, Film Producers Guild and Films of Scotland

results.title: Riverboats remembered: Murray paddlesteamers on film 1920's-1970's
results.creator_credit: Ken Berryman, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and Christine Rayfield
results.brief_description: Relive the history of the Murray riverboats from the 1920s to the 1970s; from the declining cargo trade to their restoration for the resurgent tourist market. This documentary consists almost entirely of rare archival footage and reveals the people, places and memorable events of the Murray region’s past. It includes original footage of many vessels which have been restored or earmarked for recommissioning such as the famous paddlesteamers Adelaide and Pevensey, and others which have long since disappeared.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Berryman, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and Christine Rayfield

results.title: Riverboat heritage
results.creator_credit: Russell Hurley Film Productions, Russell Hurley and Brad Smart
results.brief_description: Provides a comprehensive chronological history of the riverboats that travelled the major rivers, particularly the Murray. Portrays the transportation of supplies to inland farmers and goldseekers and the transportation of farm products to the markets of yesteryear. to the service of the tourist trade of today. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: River, where do you come from?
results.brief_description: A river’s life is traced from its origin in water evaporation from the ocean to its final return to the sea. On its way, the river serves man’s need for transport, recreation, power; is polluted by his wastes; and wreaks havon on his creations as a flood. The lyrics of a folk ballad provide the narration.

results.title: River with a problem
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, David Bairstow, Guy Glover and Graham Parker
results.brief_description: A film on water pollution, using the Ottawa River as an example of what happens when a river is used as a dumping place for municipal and industrial waste. Color animation illustrates exactly what happens to river water as it becomes polluted. Engineers, health authorities and civic officials voice concern over this increasingly urgent problem.

results.title: River watch
results.creator_credit: Roger Morin, ONF | NFB and Sydney Newman
results.brief_description: The story of how the St. Lawrence River is kept open for navigation is told, mentioning the parts played by lighthouses, marker buoys and ice breakers.

results.title: River to cross
results.creator_credit: R.K. Neilson Baxter and Basic Films
results.brief_description: An account of preliminary experiments carried out by scientists and engineers on the Severn Bridge Project 1946-49. Aspects of the work covered include: testing of foundation soils; echo-sounding of river bed; risks involved in building a suspension bridge; testing of model bridges with covered and open sides; final wind tests for oscillation on 1/100 scale model of proposed bridge.
